issues.title: Security Consideration: Audience-restricted access tokens
issues.author: aaronpk
issues.body: The security concern is when there are two separate RSs with different sets of scopes, it shouldn't be possible for RS1 to tell the client to ask for scopes for RS2, and then have RS1 be able to use the access token at RS2. Audience-restricted access tokens and resource indicators are a solution.

issues.title: Question: What should the WWW-Authenticate header return
issues.author: aaronpk
issues.body:
Should the header return the full path to the Resource Metadata document, or return the resource identifier?

* RS Metadata document: the client fetches the exact URL returned
* Resource Identifier: the client builds the metadata URL by appending .well-known... and then fetches the URL

What are the implications of this for resources that differ by path? (see mailing list thread about path-based resources that require different scopes)

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
I'm increasingly of the view that the resource identifier should be returned, which is what the draft already does.  This aligns with the `resource` value in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8707.html , which we normatively use.

I propose that we say that during IETF 118 in Prague.  If we get consensus on this, it will close our last remaining issue.

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body:
> I'm increasingly of the view that the resource identifier should be returned, which is what the draft already does. This aligns with the resource value in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8707.html , which we normatively use.

I'm wondering why the [related PR](https://github.com/oauth-wg/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata/pull/20) ended up the other route (advertising the URI of the resource metadata instead).

Advertising the resource identifier in the `WWW-Authenticate` would be more consistent with existing OAuth specifications as you pointed out.

Advertising the resource identifier in the `WWW-Authenticate` would make it possible for the client application to fetch an application-specific metadata documents (`/.well-known/myapplication-protected-resource/foo`) if it can handle it and the generic one (`/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/foo`) otherwise.

issues.title: .well-known endpoint resolution
issues.author: panva
issues.body:
The draft [currently](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01#section-3) (and the examples in it) follow this language

> Protected resources supporting metadata MUST make a JSON document containing metadata as specified in [Section 2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01#PRMetadata) available at a path formed by concatenating a well-known URI string such as /.well-known/oauth-protected-resource to the protected resource's resource identifier.

This means (taken from an example in the draft):

```
    GET /resource1/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource HTTP/1.1
    Host: resource.example.com
```

This is inconsistent with RFC8414 (and its normative dependencies) which says

> If the issuer identifier value contains a path component, any terminating "/" MUST be removed before inserting "/.well-known/" and the well-known URI suffix between the host component and the path component.

This means (taken from an example in RFC8414):

```
     GET /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server/issuer1 HTTP/1.1
     Host: example.com
```

The RFC8414 way kind of hampers the ability to host these documents in multi-tenant system on certain deployments but i'm unsure if we can justify not doing it this way.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: Thanks @panva, this was the subject of my comments in [the meeting today](https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-118-oauth#Protected-Resource-Metadata-%E2%80%93-Mike-Jones-Aaron-Parecki-20-min). I do think that the way it's done in the draft currently makes sense for the context and is preferable.  But it might raise some objections in IESG etc. review. I don't honestly know what the best course of action is. But wanted to bring it up earlier rather than later. Perhaps Roman's suggestion of asking the HTTP directorate for an early review in hope of avoiding surprise down the line?

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body:
The draft does say the following [here](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01.html#section-3.1-6), which maybe provides sufficient justification. Maybe.

> Using path components enables supporting multiple resources per host. This is required in some multi-tenant hosting configurations. This use of .well-known is for supporting multiple resources per host; unlike its use in [[RFC5785](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01.html#RFC5785)], it does not provide general information about the host.

issues.title: Section 3 Change "applications" to "deployment"
issues.author: aaronpk
issues.body:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-03.html#section-3

Change "applications" to "deployment" for clarity

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
Looking at making the change, there are ~12 places we'd be changing "application" to "deployment" and it's not clear that it would improve the readability or clarity of the text.  Furthermore, I'll also point out that this is the language used in RFC 8414, and it seems to have worked for people there, so I'm reluctant to make this change, given I don't think it would be a significant enough improvement to warrant being different.

cc @PieterKas

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body:
My comment about this section was that it was generally quite hard to follow, not that "application" should be replaced by "deployment". 

This sentence took a while to parse: "Different applications utilizing OAuth protected resources in application-specific ways may define and register different well-known URI path suffixes used to publish protected resource metadata as used by those applications. "

I think the intent here is to say that an application may be composed of different OAuth protected resources, and each of those may have their own protected resource metadata, and if this is the case, your describing a scheme on how the application may expose the resource metadata to clients for each of the underlying OAuth protected resources. If that is the intent, changing from "application" to "deployment" may not help (these are different concepts). 

Perhaps just an introductory sentence for that paragraph - something like: "An application may access multiple OAuth protected resources in order to complete an operation. Each OAuth protected resource may have their own resource metadata. In this case, the application may define and register different well-known URI path suffixes used to publish protected resource metadata as used by those applications to enable a client to obtain the resource metadata for each of the underlying resources.

As I write this, I think my confusion here was more about the lack of clarity on the relationship of the application (which may itself be an OAuth protected resource?) and the OAuth protected resources (which it relies on to perform an action).

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
@aaronpk talked about this in Rome.  The term "application", as used, encompasses all the components used to accomplish the task for the use case.  That can include OAuth clients, authorization servers, and protected resources, inclusive of the code running in each of them.  Applications are built to solve particular problems and may utilize many components and services.

I could add an introductory remark derived from the above, if that would work for you.  (Although I would try to make it more concise.)

issues.title: Usage of /.well-known/ as specified is not licit
issues.author: randomstuff
issues.body:
The current draft states:

> The consumer of the metadata would make the following request when the resource identifier is https://resource.example.com/resource1 […]
>
>     GET /resource1/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource HTTP/1.1
>     Host: resource.example.com
> 
> Using path components enables supporting multiple resources per host. This is required in some multi-tenant hosting configurations. This use of .well-known is for supporting multiple resources per host; unlike its use in [[RFC5785](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01.html#RFC5785)], it does not provide general information about the host.

AFAIU, this approach does not respect the idea of RFC5785 which is to have a dedicated path **prefix**:

> To address this, this memo defines a **path prefix** in HTTP(S) URIs for
> these "well-known locations", "/.well-known/".

Moreover, this is not consistent with [server medata](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8414#section-3.1) spec (which is completely similar):

> The client would make the following request when the
> issuer identifier is "https://example.com/issuer1" and the well-known
> URI suffix is "oauth-authorization-server" to obtain the metadata,
> since the issuer identifier contains a path component:
> 
>     GET /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server/issuer1 HTTP/1.1
>     Host: example.com

Therefore, I believe, the correct behavior would be to use `/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/resource1`.

This does not preclude a multi-tenant application from serving the same information at `/resource1/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` as well in order to facilitate exposing `https://service/resource1` as `https://resource1/`.

This does not preclude either redirecting `/app1/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` to `/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/app1` when serving multiple independant applications under the same origin.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: This behavior was corrected in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata/02/.

issues.title: The client cannot tells whether audience restriction has been applied
issues.author: randomstuff
issues.body:
The current draft contains the wording:

> While this attack is not explicitly enabled by this specification, and is possible in a plain OAuth 2.0 deployment, it is made somewhat more likely by the use of dynamically-configured clients. As such, the use of audience-restricted access tokens and **Resource Indicators [[RFC8707](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata-01.html#RFC8707)] is RECOMMENDED** when using the features in this specification.

However there is currently no way for the OAuth client to know (in the general case i.e. loose coupling between the different actors) that the audience restriction has been properly supported and applied by authorization server. For example, the authorization server might silently ignore the `resource` parameter of the authorization request.

Ideally, the authorization server should probably include the `resource` back in the authorization response similar to how this is done for the `scope` parameter (and in a sense for the [`authorization_details` parameter](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-rar-21.html#name-token-response)). Such an option should probably have been included in [RFC8707](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8707), however.

Alternatively (or in addition) some authorization server metadata could be used to indicate that it supports resource indication.

comments.author: aaronpk
comments.body: I agree that the token response should include `resource` like it does `scope` to inform the client. However I don't think that is a mechanism that this spec can suggest or define, it probably should have been part of RFC8707. Same goes for the authorization server metadata to indicate support, that should have been part of 8707, and isn't something this spec can define.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: I agree with Aaron's assessment that this is out of scope for this specification.  I'm prone to close this issue on that basis.

issues.title: Ambiguous handling of the resource_metadata WWW-Authenticate parameter
issues.author: randomstuff
issues.body:
The current draft [specifies that](https://drafts.oauth.net/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata.html#name-protected-resource-metadata-v):

> If the protected resource metadata was retrieved from a URL returned by the protected resource via the WWW-Authenticate resource_metadata parameter, then the resource value returned MUST be identical to the URL that the client used to make the request to the resource server. If these values are not identical, the data contained in the response MUST NOT be used.

If I am reading this currently, if the client makes a request to `https://resource.example.com/api/foo`, then the metadata must contain `"resource": "https://resource.example.com/api/foo"` but not something like `"resource": "https://resource.example.com/api/"` (and therefore the resource_metadata must be `https://resource.example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/api/foo`.

On the other hand, the [metadata example](https://drafts.oauth.net/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata/draft-ietf-oauth-resource-metadata.html#name-protected-resource-metadata-r) uses:

~~~json
"resource": "https://resource.example.com",
~~~

This suggests that the draft would encourage using a root API resource identifier (instead of a resource identifier for each path). 

Should the authorization server return a different metadata document URI path?

Or should the authorization server return metadata document for a base (API) path? In this case, the requirement should probably be modified to something like:

> If the protected resource metadata was retrieved from a URL returned by the protected resource via the WWW-Authenticate resource_metadata parameter, then **the URL that the client used to make the request to the resource server must be in scope of the the resource value returned**. Otherwise, the data contained in the response MUST NOT be used.

Moreover, should the client check that the `resource_metadata` URI is the same URI as the one found by applying the `/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` transformation to the "resource" metadata value? (i.e. should the client check that `resource_metadata_uri == origin + "/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource" + request_path`?)

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
Yes, as the spec says, they must be identical.

The example is just an example and happens not to include a path.  Both this spec and RFC 8707 allow the resource identifier to include a path component.

Yes, I would have also preferred that WWW-Authenticate return the "resource" value rather than the "resource_metadata" value.  In fact, it did until draft -02.  But the working group felt otherwise, and as we're past both WGLC and IETF last call, I'm not prone to try to reopen that issue at this point in time.

comments.body: There should be a `.` at the end of this sentence.

@aaronpk and @selfissued, Is the intent here that if no key usage is specified, the keys are signing keys? Why not always be explicit. Either explicitly state that all keys are signing keys by default, and if encryption keys are used, key usage should be added, or alternatively make a key usage parameter mandatory, whether the keys are signing keys only, or if there are a mix of signing and encryption keys.

reviews.author: PieterKas
reviews.body:
The proposed text makes the key usage implicit, unless otherwise stated. It is also unclear if it is OK to include key usage even if there are only signing keys. 

From an implementation perspective, this creates complexity as there are now two cases to handle (1) implicit (no usage and unclear what to do if key usage is present only for signing keys - assumption is honour it, but perhaps better to be explicit) and (2) parse key usage if present. 

By removing the implicit option and always forcing key usage it removes the additional ambiguity and simplified code (i.e. always check for key usage, if no key usage, error).

Suggestion:

Replace: 

When both signing and encryption keys are made available, a <spanx style="verb">use</spanx> (public key use) parameter value is REQUIRED for all keys in the referenced JWK Set to indicate each key's intended usage.

With:

"A <spanx style="verb">use</spanx> (public key use) parameter value is REQUIRED for all keys in the referenced JWK Set to indicate each key's intended usage.

comments.body:
This is exactly the same language as in the `jwks_uri` definition at https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8414.html#section-2.  I would rather keep the OAuth metadata specs consistent in their treatment of this parameter.

Are you OK approving this on that basis, @PieterKas ?  Thanks.

@selfissued thanks for pointing that out. 

I was thinking through whether we will break something if we move away from the implicit key usage defined in the Authorization Server Metadata spec and concluded that we probably end up making the developers life more difficult as they now have two different models for validating resource metadata, creating opportunity for confusion and reducing re-use. So assuming they are parsing and validating authorization server metadata correctly, they should be able to do the same for resource metadata. So, I think with that, I am good with approving the changes.

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body:
Small comments:

* One confusing thing is that `dpop_bound_access_tokens` declares that RS **always requires** DPoP whereas `tls_client_certificate_bound_access_tokens`** declares whether the Rs supports mTLS-bound access tokens.
* I am wondering if `dpop_bound_access_tokens` makes sense in the context of the RS. It makes a lot of sens =e in the context of the client application bit it might make more sense for the RS to have a parameter which says "I always require sender-constrained access tokens" in order to different different type of clients (?).

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
As I'm sure you can tell, I reused the existing metadata values from the DPoP and MTLS specs, applying them here.  That seemed like at least the right starting point.  I agree that the two mechanisms aren't parallel (including that there's no way to specify what MTLS algorithms are supported).

If we do anything else, I would prefer to add something like an `access_token_types_supported` field with defined values `[bearer, mtls, dpop]` and delete `dpop_bound_access_tokens`.

What do people think?

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body: Note: I would expect `access_token_types_supported` to list actually defined `acces_token_types` (from the [registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/oauth-parameters/oauth-parameters.xhtml#token-types)) and `mtls` is not one of them because it (typically) uses `"token_type":"bearer"`.

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body: I would suggest simply removing `dpop_bound_access_tokens` because I am not sure it is useful. However, I am not sure if this is right or wrong.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Good point about access token types having a registry and MTLS not being in the registry.  So we shouldn't do what I proposed in the comments.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
Having `dpop_bound_access_tokens` to say that DPoP tokens are required is very useful.  It means that the WWW-Authenticate dance saying that the client has to use DPoP shown in Figure 15 at https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9449.html#http-401-response-protected-req-without-auth can be skipped - saving a protocol round trip.

So I'm thinking that we should leave the metadata parameters as they are in the PR.

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body:
> Having dpop_bound_access_tokens to say that DPoP tokens are required is very useful. It means that the WWW-Authenticate dance saying that the client has to use DPoP shown in Figure 15 at https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9449.html#http-401-response-protected-req-without-auth can be skipped - saving a protocol round trip.

This *could* be supported by the `access_token_types_supported` parameter (which could have the `bearer` and `DPoP` values).

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
@randomstuff, you talked me out of `access_token_types_supported` earlier because it's a mix of things with and outside of an existing registry.  And I believe you were right.

I'm prone to leave things as-is, pending @aaronpk's feedback.

comments.author: aaronpk
comments.body:
I agree the mismatch of DPoP *required* vs MTLS *supported* is weird.

>  I reused the existing metadata values from the DPoP and MTLS specs, applying them here

Which DPoP metadata is that? I see one for [client metadata](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9449#section-12.10) which indicates whether the client always uses DPoP for token requests. But that isn't the same thing. It is also only about the token *request* to the authorization server, not about requests to the resource server.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
One gets the DPoP-supported bit from whether `dpop_signing_alg_values_supported` is present or not.  So you have _supported_ bits for both mechanisms.

The difference between DPoP and MTLS that this PR tries to accurately reflect is that DPoP has a mechanism to say that DPoP is required whereas MTLS doesn't.  The required bit for DPoP is in `dpop_bound_access_tokens`.  I decided not to add such a bit for MTLS, but could if you guys feel that it's needed.

comments.author: aaronpk
comments.body: I see, that's fine. Can we make it more explicit and make it `dpop_bound_access_tokens_required` so that at least we don't have the inconsistency of `tls_client_certificate_bound_access_tokens` meaning "supported" and `dpop_bound_access_tokens` meaning "required"?

comments.author: randomstuff
comments.body:
@aaronpk, the inconsistency comes from [RFC9447](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9449.html#name-client-registration-metadat), which defines `dpop_bound_access_tokens` as:

> A boolean value specifying whether the client always uses DPoP for token requests. If omitted, the default value is false.

I agree that this should probably have been named `dpop_bound_access_token(s)_required` instead but here we are.

Now, it probably makes sense to use the same (arguably bogus) name here for the same semantic.

comments.author: aaronpk
comments.body: I actually think it's not necessary to use the same term, since RFC9447 is talking about it from the opposite point of view. In 9447 it's about whether the *client* always uses DPoP, whereas what we're talking about is whether the *server* requires DPoP. It would be weird in 9447 to use `_required`, since the semantic is not that the client *requires* DPoP, it's about whether the client always includes DPoP proofs in its requests. So the semantic is actually different.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Based on the discussion here, I changed `dpop_bound_access_tokens` to `dpop_bound_access_tokens_required`.
